content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays multiple pieces of tissue stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). I can identify approximately six distinct, well-circumscribed, ovoid structures that are intensely basophilic (purple), which are characteristic of lymph nodes. The remaining tissue is more fragmented, paler (pink), and appears to be composed mainly of adipose (fat) tissue, with some fragments that might represent the primary tumor or wall of the colon. The overall impression is that this slide contains lymph nodes and associated fatty tissue from a colorectal resection specimen.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

The green box is strategically placed at the interface between one of the smaller lymphoid aggregates and adjacent tissue. As a pathologist, assessing a colorectal cancer case involves staging the tumor. This requires examining the primary tumor for depth of invasion (T stage) and the lymph nodes for metastasis (N stage). I would zoom into this area because it shows the junction of three important components: a potential lymph node, what could be colorectal mucosa or tumor, and the surrounding adipose tissue. Examining this interface is crucial to determine if there is tumor invasion into the pericolic fat (relevant for T staging) or if there is tumor extension into or metastasis within the lymph node (relevant for N staging). This is a high-yield area to look for key prognostic features. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my protocol is to systematically examine every lymph node present in the specimen. The green box is centered on one of the smaller lymph nodes located in the lower portion of the image. I would zoom into this area to assess the architecture of the lymph node, specifically examining the subcapsular sinus and the parenchyma for the presence of atypical cells or glandular structures that are not native to a lymph node, which would be indicative of metastatic carcinoma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my goal is to examine every lymph node for evidence of metastasis. The area indicated by the green box is centered on one of the larger, well-circumscribed lymph nodes (the second from the top, in the upper central part of the slide). It's a logical place to begin the systematic evaluation of the lymph nodes to assess their architecture and screen for tumor deposits. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my protocol for staging colorectal cancer requires the meticulous examination of every lymph node identified. The area in the green box clearly delineates one of these lymph nodes. I am zooming in to assess its architecture and cellular composition at higher magnification to search for any metastatic tumor cells, which would appear as atypical epithelial cells, often forming glands or clusters, contrasting with the normal lymphocyte population. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, on the left, I see glandular tissue consistent with colorectal mucosa. The crypts are visible, although there is some architectural irregularity and a dense inflammatory infiltrate in the lamina propria, particularly in the upper portion. On the right, there is a large field of mature adipose tissue (fat cells). The view is focused on the boundary between the glandular tissue and the fat. My impression is that this is the edge of a piece of the colon wall or a large polyp, abutting the pericolic fat. While I don't see definitive malignant glands infiltrating the fat in this specific field of view, the presence of glandular elements directly adjacent to the fat is suspicious and necessitates careful examination of the entire interface to determine if this represents the invasive front of an adenocarcinoma, which would be critical for T-staging.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows the interface between the lymph node and the surrounding pericapsular adipose tissue. On the left, there is a dense population of small, dark, round cells, which are lymphocytes, confirming this is lymphoid tissue. At the edge of the lymphoid aggregate and infiltrating into the fibro-adipose tissue on the right, there are clusters and nests of atypical cells. These cells are larger than the lymphocytes, have more eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, and pleomorphic, hyperchromatic nuclei. This morphology is inconsistent with normal lymphoid or adipose tissue and is highly characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic carcinoma. The presence of tumor cells in the fatty tissue outside the main lymphoid aggregate is also suspicious for extranodal extension.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows the histology of the lymph node. It is composed of a dense population of lymphocytes. I can see evidence of lymphoid follicles, some with germinal centers, suggesting a reactive process. The majority of the cells are small, mature-appearing lymphocytes. There are no obvious clusters of large, atypical epithelial cells or glandular structures to suggest metastatic carcinoma in this field of view. My impression is that this portion of the lymph node shows reactive changes and is likely negative for malignancy, although the entire node would need to be carefully examined to confirm this.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows a section of a lymph node and adjacent perinodal adipose tissue. The lymph node itself is composed of a dense, monotonous population of small, dark-staining cells with scant cytoplasm, which are morphologically consistent with mature lymphocytes. The overall architecture appears to be that of a reactive lymph node, with preserved follicles and sinuses. I do not see any definitive evidence of metastatic carcinoma, such as clusters of atypical glandular cells or signet ring cells. My impression is that this is a benign, reactive lymph node, negative for malignancy.
